Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is an investigation into the representation theory and cohomology of finite groups and algebras over fields of prime characteristic. The Principal Investigator is particularly interested in the homological properties of representations which underlie the basic module theory. In the area of group representations he will continue his long investigation into the connections between module theory and group cohomology. Specific problems are concerned with the classification of endotrivial modules which define the stable equivalences of Morita type for the group algebra. The Principal Investigator will study other basic issues concerned with the linear algebra of representations of finite groups and group schemes and connections with the theory of bundles. The proposed work will build on the foundation laid by the Principal investigator over many years. In addition, he plans to continue his development of computer algebra systems for experimentation with modules and homomorphisms. Recent work has led to the development of systems for analyzing and condensing matrix algebras down to their basic algebras. The system will be expanded to investigate general homological properties for finite dimensional algebras as well as application to group representations. Other projects involve connections with the representation theory of algebraic groups and the general theory of group extensions.

The Principal Investigator will look at algebraic systems together with the actions of operators. Such a system might be a space with the operators being rotations or some representation of progression over time. The system is called a module and it might have many dimensions in the sense of depending on many variable. The project will concentrate on the classification of collections of certain types of modules whose associated operators whose interactions satisfy preset conditions. A significant part of the project is the development of computational techniques and software for analyzing the structure and properties of modules. Groups of transformations on modules and spaces are basic objects in modern mathematics and arise in many applications of the mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Representation theory is the study of actions on spaces. The actions
can be viewed a rotations or translations or deformations of the space
as long at they take lines to lines. The collection of actions on the
space is called a group if there is only one operation (performing
the actions one after another) and every actions is reversible. The
collection of actions is an algebra if the actions can also be added.
The space together with the action is called a module for the group
or algebra. Groups and algebras are fundamental objects at the core of
many applications, and they are characterized by their modules, by
how they act on spaces. Modules are connected to each other by functions
that preserve the action of the group or algebra. For example, if a
subspace such as a line or plan is invariant under the actions of the
group ore algebra then it is itself a module. In this way the collection
of all modules for the group or algebra (called the category of modules)
is endowed with a structure that has importance for many applications
and insights.

Most of the theoretical aspects of the grant revolve around study of
the category of modules over a group. Among the major accomplishments
is a new proof of the classification of certain important subcategories
of the category of all modules. The proof provides some new insights
into the cohomology, which is the glue that connects module together,
as well as a connection to the area of commutative algebra. In another
direction, the Principal Investigator and his collaborators have made
significant progress on the classification of endotrivial modules. These
are specific modules that are important for several reasons, one being
that the they generate equivalences on the category of modules, thus
giving us different ways of looking at categories. The new results
connect the structure of the collection of endotrivial modules to the
structure of the group of actions on the module. This has the potential
to lead to a complete solution to the problem of the classification of
endotrivial modules in the near future.

Another important accomplishment of the Principal Investigator and his
collaborators is the introduction of a new collections of invariants on
modules. A module of constant Jordan type is a module such that the
actions of element of the algebra appear to be all the same. That is,
they have diifferent forms, but one of these actions looks the same as
another when the space of the module is viewed from a different direction.
This notion has been extended to the actions of more than one element.
Modules of constant radical or socle type occur natrually in many places
in mathematics and in the universe. The interesting development is that
they give rise to a new connection with the algebraic geometry. Several
papers written by the Principal Investigator and his collaborators
explore the structure of these module and the geometric connections.

On a somewhat more practical side, the Principal Investigator has
continued to develop his algorithms and computer programs aimed at the
analysis of modules over matrix algebras. In this case a matrix algebra
is one that is generated by a few rotations or transformations on a space.
So an element of the algebra is obtained by adding and multiplying the
few generators in various combinations. The programs of the Principal
Investigator extract a systematic decomposition of the algebra that
illuminates its structure. In the period of the grant, several improvements
have been made to the package of programs and a great deal of functionality
for calculating important aspects of the algebra structure has been added.
